results.title: The Power of one
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Studio Canal+, Regency Enterprises, Alcor Films, Arnon Milchan and John G. Avildsen
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Bryce Courtenay, this is the story of a young English boy named PK. Orphaned in a foreign land and terrorized for his political beliefs by his schoolmates, the pint-sized youngster turns to the only friend who can help him: a kindly yet world-wise prison inmate who teaches him how to box. As he grows into manhood, he takes on the system and social injustices which arise from Apartheid. Stars Stephen Dorff, Morgan Freeman and Sir John Gielgud and photographed by Australian Dean Semler. One person really can make a difference.

results.title: The Power of mentoring
results.brief_description: Mentoring is where an experienced individual invests time, energy and personal knowledge to assist another person. This management title discusses successful mentoring behaviours and follows two main mentoring relationships and their development. Also shown is a mentoring situation which isn’t working, demonstrating that mentoring requires an equal input from both partners. A 51 page training program accompanies this title.

results.title: The Power of Love
results.creator_credit: Nat G. Deverich and Harry K. Fairall
results.brief_description: The first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience was The Power of Love (1922), which used the red-and-green anaglyph system that most people associate with 3D. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour.

constellations_primary.name: The power of alternate endings
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation about alternate perspectives, dream states, sitcoms and spin-offs was made by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Daniel Bryan.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Nat G. Deverich and Harry K. Fairall
results.description:
Though experiments into stereoscopic movies started back in 1889, filmmaker Edwin S Porter projected the first 3D test film in 1915. He used the red-and-green anaglyph system that most people associate with 3D. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour, that gave the illusion of depth when superimposed.

The same system was used for The Power of Love (1922), the first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience. And 3D wasn’t that film’s only innovation: viewers could choose different endings by peering through only the red or green lens. It was the only film released using the Fairall-Elder stereoscopic camera pictured here.
description_for_label:
Though experiments into stereoscopic movies started back in 1889, filmmaker Edwin S Porter projected the first 3D test film in 1915. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour, that gave the illusion of depth when superimposed.

The same system was used for The Power of Love (1922), the first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience. And 3D wasn’t that film’s only innovation: viewers could choose different endings by peering through only the red or green lens. It was the only film released using the Fairall-Elder stereoscopic camera pictured here.

results.title: The Power of listening
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the meaning and benefits of active listening, problems associated with being an effective listener, deterrents to good listening skills and specific techniques to improve listening abilities.

results.title: The Power makers
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Lee Robinson
results.brief_description: The film depicts a working day for a dredge operator, a train driver, a foreman and a turbine attendant at the open cut brown coal mine and power station at Yallourn, Victoria. These men join with thousands of others to convert the brown coal into electricity; the technical processes involved are shown incidentally.

results.title: The Power game (A)
results.creator_credit: University of Wollongong and Jane Innes
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia”.
The third episode in the “Millennium dilemma” series explores the division of power in the Parliament and the Executive in Australia, with particular attention to Federal and State Powers and their differences. The program offers definitions of and discussions about Parliament and the Executive as well as Federal, State and Local governments by the range of contributors to the program, along with their responsive commentary about questions such as, is there a ‘State and Federal Fiscal Imbalance? What is the power of external affairs? These interviewees include politicians, political analysts, media commentators, academics and legal counsel such as Professor Brian Galligan, UN member Elizabeth Evatt, Justice Michael Kirby, Kim Rubenstein, Kristen Walker, Sir Ninian Stephen and Professor Cheryl Saunders.

results.title: The Power and the people [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Steeplechase Films, WGBH (Boston), Thirteen, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.), New York Historical Society, Ric Burns and Lisa Ades
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “New York: a documentary film”.
Episode 4: THE POWER AND THE PEOPLE (1898-1918) follows New York into the new century examining the interplay of capitalism, democracy and transformation, in the wake of an extraordinary wave of immigration, the building of the subway and the birth of the skyscraper. During a single generation, over 10 million immigrants arrived in New York. Arising from the plight of the city’s most exploited citizens came reform legislation that would become the template for the New Deal. Narrated by David Ogden Stiers.

results.title: The Powder room
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Michael Allder and Ann Kennard
results.brief_description: The Powder room journeys through a number of ladies restrooms throughout Canada and the United States, interviewing women and capturing through their tales an often invisible part of our cultural life. Through observations of her own, director Ann Kennard felt the need to document this female ritual and in doing so manages to explore an important way in which women socialise and impart information about their personal lives. The intimacies and morals of women find their way into the bathroom and therefore find a voice and an antidote to their isolation. Subjects discussed include sexuality, orgasm, dating, sex, boyfriends, infidelity, teenage pregnancy, sexual attitudes, body image, sexual practices.
